metadata.title: Development strategies and prospects of nano-based smart pesticide formulation

sections.text:
Pesticides are important inputs for enhancing crop productivity and preventing major 14 biological disasters. However, more than 90% of pesticides run off into the 15 environment and residue in agricultural products in process of application, due to the 16 disadvantages of conventional pesticide formulation such as use of harmful solvent, 17 poor dispersion, dust drift, etc. In recent years, using nanotechnology to create novel 18 formulations has shown great potential in improving the efficacy and safety of 19 pesticides. The development of nano-based pesticide formulation aims at precise 20 release of necessary and sufficient amounts of their active ingredients, in responding 21 to environmental triggers and biological demands through controlled release 22 mechanisms. This paper discusses several scientific issues and strategies regarding 23 development of nano-based pesticide formulations: (i) Construction of water-based 24 dispersion pesticide nanoformulation; (ii) Mechanism on leaf-targeted deposition and 25 dose transfer of pesticide nano-delivery system; (iii) Mechanism on increased 26
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
bioavailability of nano-based pesticide formulation; and (iv) Impacts of 27 nanoformulation on natural degradation and bio-safety of pesticide residues. 28
29 KEYWORDS: nanoformulation, pesticide, nanotechnology, agriculture, 30 nano-delivery system 31
32 1. Introduction 33 Pesticides play an important role in defensing of biological disasters, ensuring 34 the crop productivity and promoting the sustained steady growth of agricultural 35 production 1 . According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United 36 Nations (FAO) statistics, pest and pathogen control with pesticides has restored 30% 37
of total output of agricultural products all over the world 2,3 . However, indiscriminate 38 pesticide usage also brings a serious threat to the environment and human health. The 39 annual input amounts of pesticides have reached 4.6 million tons worldwide, 90% of 40 which run off into the environment, residue in agricultural products and redistribute in 41
ecological cycle during application 4-10 . Inefficient use of pesticides causes a series of 42 ecological environment problems, such as pathogen and pest resistance, non-point 43 pollution, water eutrophication, soil degradation, bioaccumulation in food chain, and 44 loss of biodiversity (Figure 1). 45
46
Page 2 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
. The loss and decomposition rate of pesticide 53
on crop foliar is typically up to 70%, caused by run-off, spray drift and rolling down 54
during field application 12,13 . The actual utilization of biological target uptake is only 55
less than 0.1% after dust drift and rainwater leaching 14,15 (Figure 2). The off-target 56 loss is the crucial problem for inefficient usage of conventional pesticide 57
formulations 13,16 . Wettable powder (WP) and emulsifiable concentrate (EC) are two 58 major conventional pesticide formulations. WP is a crushed powder pesticide 59 formulation composed of pesticide AIs, inert fillers and other additives. The inorganic 60 fillers in WP easily drift and run off into the environment, and the loaded AIs cannot 61 be completely released. In addition, the residual pesticides are difficult to be degraded. 62 EC is a liquid pesticide formulation. Pesticide AIs are dissolved in the solvent, added 63 with emulsifier, and then diluted into water to form a stable emulsion. The organic 64
Page 3 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
solvents and toxic ingredients directly leach and leak into the environment while 65 pesticide spraying, resulting serious pollutants in soil and water system, chemical 66
residues in crops and food products, and potential threat to human health 17 . These 67 environmental problems and health risks has aroused the universal concerns. 68
69
great potential for alleviation of these problems 18-20 . Nano-based smart formulation 76 could release their AIs in responding to environmental triggers and biological 77 demands more precisely through targeted delivery or controlled release mechanisms. 78 Developing new advanced nano-based formulations that remain stable and active in 79 the spray condition (sun, heat, rain), penetrate and delivery to the target, prolong the 80 effective duration, and reduce the run-off in environment, is one of the hotspots in the 81
field of nano-technical agriculture applications 11,21,22 . In 2003, United States 82 Department of Agriculture (USDA) firstly launched the Nanoscale Science and 83 Engineering for Agriculture and Food Systems Research Program, smart delivery 84
systems of agricultural chemicals was one of the key research directions 23 . In 2009, 85
Page 4 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) held the International Conference on Food 86 and Agriculture Applications of Nanotechnologies, and published a strategic research 87
report on the prospects of nanotechnologies in agriculture 24 . Recent years, United 88 States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and European Commission have 89
successively enacted rules on the management and usage of nanopesticides 25,26 . Bayer, 90 DuPont, Syngenta and other agrochemical enterprises also pay great attention to the 91 development of nano-based pesticide formulations, and some products has been 92
applied to crop production or plant protection 24 . 93
94 2. Nano-based pesticide formulation: properties and advantages 95 Nanotechnology involves manufacture, manipulation, and application of 96
ultrafine materials that have at least one size dimension in the order of 1-100nm 27 . 97 Particles have unique properties such as size-dependent qualities, high 98 surface-to-volume ratio and unique optical properties at a critical length scale of less 99
than 100 nm 11 . However, because other phenomena (transparency, turbidity, stable 100 dispersion, etc.) that extend the upper limit are occasionally considered, a broader 101 definition of nano-based pesticide formulations is accepted as systems with 102 dimensions smaller than 500 nm, exhibit novel properties associated with their small 103
size 19,28-30 . 104 Nanomaterials held great promise regarding their application in nano-based 105 pesticide formulation due to their small size, big surface area and target modified 106 properties. Nano-based formulation may bring beneficial improvements in properties 107 and behaviors of pesticides, such as solubility, dispersion, stability, mobility and 108 targeting delivery. Furthermore, it might significantly improve the efficacy, safety and 109 economic effects of traditional pesticides by increasing efficacy, extending effect 110
Page 5 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
duration, reducing dose required, providing capability to controlled release of active 111 ingredients, and improving stability of payloads from the environment; subsequently 112 diminishing run-off and environmental residuals (Figure 3). 113
114
modified functional groups of nanoparticles are critical factors in their application 31 . A 119 broad variety of natural or synthesized materials are used in construction of pesticide 120 nanoformulations, such as metal, metal oxides, non-metal oxides, carbon, silicates, 121 ceramics, clays, layered double hydroxides, polymers, lipids, dendrimers, proteins, 122
quantum dots, and so on 32-36 . Nano-pesticides may be developed by two pathways, 123 directly processing into nanoparticles (nanosized pesticides), and loading pesticides 124
with nano-carriers in delivery systems 11 . In nano-carrier systems, pesticides are 125 loaded through: encapsulation inside the nanoparticulate polymeric shell, absorption 126 onto the nanoparticle surface, attachment on the nanoparticle core via ligands, or 127 entrapment within the polymeric matrix (Figure 4). 128 A variety of nanoformulation types have been developed, including 129 nanoemulsions, nanocapsules, nanospheres, nanosuspensions, solid lipid nanoparticles, 130
Page 6 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
mesoporous nanoparticles, and nanoclays 37-41 . Aqueous nanoemulsion and 131 nanosuspension of pesticides increase solubility of water insoluble AIs, eliminate the 132 toxic organic solvents, and would gradually substitute the conventionally EC 133
products 42-44 . Nanocapsule and nanosphere are suggested as vehicles for the 134 environmentally sensitive pesticides, due to their capability to slow release of AIs, 135 improve stability of formulation, prevent early degradation, and extend the longevity 136
of pesticides 45-48 . Mesoporous nanoparticles, such as nanoclay, activated carbon and 137 porous hollow silica are also verified to be suitable for the controlled release and 138 delivery systems for the water-soluble and fat-dispersible pesticides which possess 139 high drug-loading capacity, good biocompatibility, low toxicity and multistage release 140
pattern 49,50 . 141
3. Challenges and scientific issues 145 The mode of pesticide application influences their efficiency and environmental 146
impact 51-53 . Insect pests and pathogens are the targets of pesticides. However, it is 147
Page 7 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
extremely difficult to directly spray the pesticides on pests or pathogens. As a result, 148 the pesticides are sprayed on the crop foliage to form an effective toxic zone, 149 maintaining the toxic stress on the pests or pathogens. Currently spraying system of 150 pesticide application needs to focus on efficacy enhancement and spray drift 151
management 11 . 152 Most of the pesticide AIs are poorly soluble, or even insoluble in water. One of 153 the challenges associated with pesticide formulation is increasing their solubility and 154 dispersion in aqueous solution. In addition, the most of crop leaf surfaces are highly 155
hydrophobic which inhibits liquid deposition 54,55 . Thus another challenge is reducing 156 the spray drift and run-off loss on the hydrophobic foliage. As shown in Figure5, 157 size-down of pesticide particles benefit to significantly improve their water-dispersion, 158 targeting coverage and insecticidal activity due to smaller particle size and higher 159 surface area. In addition, Pesticide nanoformulations increase adhesion and deposition 160 of droplets on the leaves through leaf-affinity modification. 161
162
Page 8 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
surfaces, and then the AIs deposite, release and transfer from the foliage to the pest or 167 pathogen targets, finally kill the insects or pathogens before degradation (Figure 6). 168 Therefore, water-dispersion, leaf-affinity, bio-availability and residues degradation are 169 the most critical factors regarding development of nano-based pesticide formulations. 170 Four key scientific issues for improvement of pesticide efficacy and safety are 171 proposed: (i) Construction of water-based dispersion pesticide nanoformulation; (ii) 172 Mechanism on leaf-targeted deposition and dose transfer of pesticide nano-delivery 173 system; (iii) Mechanism on increased bioavailability of nano-based pesticide 174 formulation; and (iv) Impacts of nanoformulation on natural degradation and 175 bio-safety of pesticide residues. 176
177
4. Construction of water-based dispersion pesticide nanoformulation 181 The fundamental limitation with the use of current pesticides is that they are 182
generally comprised of virtually insoluble compounds 57 . This lack of solubility 183 requires the addition of large amounts of organic solvents for dissolution and spraying 184 application in field, which increases costs, applicators' exposures and environmental 185
Page 9 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
pollutants 58 . Water-based dispersion pesticide nanoformulations improve the solubility 186 and dispersion in water, uniform leaf coverage, biological efficacy and environmental 187 compatibility, due to the small particle size, high surface area and elimination of 188
organic solvents in comparison to conventionally formulations 58-60 . 189 Synthesis of nano-based formulations involve size reduction by top-down 190 methods such as milling, high pressure homogenization and sonication, while 191 bottom-up processes involve meltdispersion, solvent displacement, complex 192
coacervation, interfacial polymerization, and emulsion diffusion 13, 61 . Nanocapsules, 193 nanoemulsions, nanospheres, nanomicelles, and nanosuspensions show great potential 194 for improving formulation properties, such as water-dispersion, chemical stability, 195 targeting adhesion, permeability and controlled release (Figure 7). 196
197
. The polymeric shell degrades slowly in the environment, thus 205
Page 10 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
improves chemical stability for environment-sensitive compounds (i.e., UV 206 degradation and soil degradation). In addition, nanocapsules can increase the targeting 207 delivery efficiency with membranal polymeric leaf-affinity modification, improving 208 the behaviors of wetting, spreading and absorbing of droplets on leaves. 209 Nanoemulsions are oil-in-water (O/W) emulsions where the pesticides are dis-210 persed as nanosized droplets in water, and the surfactant molecules localized at the 211
pesticide-water interface 71-73 . Nanoemulsions improve the efficacy and safety effects 212 of traditional pesticides, due to the small size effect, high dissolution rate and 213 elimination of toxic organic solvents. 214 Nanospheres are solid sphere vesicular systems where the pesticides are 215
uniformly distributed through adsorption or entrapment inside the nano-matrix 74-77 . 216 Nanospheres are composed of organic polymer materials or inorganic mesoporous 217 materials, such as activated carbon, non-metal oxides and porous hollow silica. 218 Nanospheres possess high drug-loading capacity, good biocompatibility and 219 slow/controlled release pattern, showing great potential in soil infection disease and 220
soil pest control 78-80 . 221 Nanomicelles are ideal bioactive smart nano delivery systems for encapsulating 222 pesticides. Nanomicelles can be induced by the external environment, and thus make 223 the corresponding changes in physical and chemical properties. For example, based 224 on the hydrogen bonding cross-linked nanomicelle, an environment-responsive 225 controlled release system was constructed. Under high temperature and high humidity 226 conditions, the hydrogen bonding fractured, the nanomicelle swelled and the 227 pesticides were released. The pesticides were blocked under low temperature and low 228
humidity conditions the other way round 81 . 229 Naonosuspensions are pesticide nanoparticles uniformly suspended in water. The 230
Page 11 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
aqueous colloid dispersion systems render higher solubility and dispersion for 231 insoluble or fat-dispersible compounds in solution, improve the pesticide 232 bioavailability, and reduce the costs due to the ease to large-scale manufacture. 233
234 5. Mechanism on leaf-targeted deposition and dose transfer of pesticide 235 nano-delivery system 236 The pesticide spray application on foliage is inadequate due to the weak adhesion 237 to the crop foliage. For the spray pesticides, pesticides are firstly deposited on crop 238 foliage, and then they go to parts of the plant attacked by a pest through diffusion, 239 uptake and/or transfer processes, leading to pest poisoning or death by active or 240
passive contact 13, 82 . Consequently, leaf hydrophobicity and pesticide droplet retention 241 are key parameters affecting the effective utilization of pesticides. As shown in Figure 242 8, the pesticide droplet forms a spherical shape, minimizing contact with the 243 hydrophobic foliage, poorly wetting and spreading on the waxy layer, and resulting in 244 loss as rolling down and run-off. After water evaporation, the residual pesticide 245 particles easily drift or fall off from the leaves, since the particles are too large to 246 embed in the microstructured or nanostructured mastoids of leaf surfaces. 247 Nano-delivery systems form stable dispersions, increase the efficiency, and 248 improve the wetting and spreading behavior on leaf surface, due to the leaf-affinity 249 modification of pesticides. In addition, the pesticide nanoparticles deposite and adhere 250 favorably on the surface of foliage, leading to increased retention rate and decreased 251 spraying dosage (Figure 8). The adhesion properties of nano-based formulation were 252 achieved by the multimodal interactions between the nanoparticles and the crop 253
foliage, such as hydrogen bonding, electrostatic attraction and covalent bonding 83 . 254 The adhesion strength strongly depended on the size distribution of nanoparticles and 255
Page 12 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
the functional groups on the nanoparticle surface, and was easily regulated by size 256
controlling and varying functional groups 82 . Carboxyl-modified nanocapsules reduced 257 the surface tension of pesticide dispersions, decreased the contact angle of droplet on 258
hydrophobic foliage, and improved the retention rate 84,85 . Additionally, increased leaf 259 coverage, improved diffusion properties, and penetration into plants were 260
observed 47,86 . 261
262
6. Mechanism on increased bioavailability of nano-based pesticide formulation 266 Compared with the traditional pesticide formulation, nano-based formulations 267 have smaller particle size and larger specific surface area, which can effectively 268 increase the coverage, adhesion and permeability of the pest. In addition, nano-based 269 formulations may affect the action modes and the transfer paths of conventional 270 pesticides by introducing insect-target modification and enhancing release of AIs 271 (Figure 9). Pesticides can be classified according to four distinctive functions: 272 stomach poisoning, the pesticide enters the body of pests via their mouthpart and 273 digestive system; inhalation poisoning, pesticides enters the body of pests via fluids 274
Page 13 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
from a consumed host organism; contact poisoning, the pesticide enters the body of 275 pests via their epidermis upon contact; and fumigation, the pesticide in gas form 276 enters the body of pests via their respiration system. It was presumed that nano-based 277 formulation might enhance the stomach poisoning and contact poisoning functions, 278 since it significantly improve the dispersal and permeability, and thus increase the rate 279
of pesticide entering pest bodies 87,88 . Furthermore, the enhancement of the transport, 280 conduction and transformation efficiency of pesticide nanoparticles inside pests can 281 accelerate pests poisoning, further improve the efficacy, bioactivity and dose effect of 282
pesticides 89 . 283
284
7. Impacts of nanoformulation on degradation and bio-safety 288 Inevitably, nanoparticles will be released into the plants and the environment system. 289 The unique physical and chemical properties of nanoparticles might cause some 290 unpredictable adverse effects on crops, agricultural products and ecosystem90-93. In 291 addition, these materials will accumulate over time in soils and rates may vary in 292 response to unknown parameters94,95. The general concern is that some nanoparticles or 293
Page 14 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
nanostructured materials may flow into the environmental systems and food chain, which 294 may become a new class of pollutant resources that threaten human health and ecosystem 295 balance. However, because farmland is an open complicated system with many 296 influencing factors of complicated functions, actual data measuring environmental 297 concentration of nanoformulations in various media is scarce96-98. The environmental fate 298 and potential bio-safety problem of nanomaterials or nanoparticles from 299 nanoformulations is also unclear99. Therefore, avoiding risk research should be conducted 300 on safety and risk assessments of nanopesticides according to the methodologies 301 established in nanotoxicology and nanomedicine. Investigating the toxicological effect, 302 environmental behavior, and pharmacokinetics of nanoparticles, studying the interaction 303 mechanism between nanoparticles and plants, and evaluating their potential impact on the 304 quality and safety of agricultural products can provide a theoretical basis for the 305 development of nanopesticides and the sustainable implementation of nanotechnology in 306 agriculture (Figure 10). On the other hand, nano-based pesticide formulation can 307 accelerate the catalytic degradation of toxic residues and reduce the pesticide residues in 308 environment by introducing bio-degradable material carriers and photocatalysts100. 309
310
Page 15 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
8. Conclusion and prospects 314
Clearly, nano-based pesticide formulations have many advantages over the 315 conventional equivalents such as high efficiency, environment friendliness, 316 high-targeting delivery and smart controlled release. Due to the technological 317 advancement, large scale applications of nanopesticides in crop production have just 318 become possible. These are the desired properties and research objectives of 319 nano-based pesticide formulations as summarized in Table 1. 320
321
324 In conclusion, nano-based pesticide formulations bring beneficial improvements 325
Page 16 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
in properties and behaviour of traditional pesticides such as solubility, dispersion, 326 stability, and targeting delivery, controlled release of active ingredients. Additionally, 327 it might not only significantly improve the bioavailability and the duration of drug 328 efficacy, but also reduce the toxicity of non-target wildlife, the food and 329 environmental residual. On the other hand, some toxic nanoparticles from pesticides 330 may flow into the environment and food systems threaten human health and 331 ecosystem balance. Avoiding risk research should be conducted on safety and risk 332 assessments of nanopesticides according to the methodologies established in 333 nanotoxicology and nanomedicine. Safer and bio-degradable nanomaterials should be 334 developed for nanopesticides production. As a most promising and attractive field of 335 nanotechnology application in agriculture, these novel agrochemical products will 336 provide multiple benefits such as reduced use of chemicals and subsequently reduced 337 water pollution and food product residual contamination, efficient use of agricultural 338 resources, increased soil and environmental qualities. 339
340 341
Page 17 of 30
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
